title-group.article-title: Did the mid-Holocene environmental changes cause the boom and bust of hunter-gatherer population size in eastern Fennoscandia?

author-notes.corresp: Miikka Tallavaara, Department of Philosophy, History, Culture and Art Studies, Archaeology, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 59, FI-00014, Finland. Email: miikka.tallavaara@helsinki.fi

abstract.p: Prehistoric hunter-gatherer population size is often assumed to follow climatic and other environmental forcings that affect environmental productivity and the availability of food for human foragers. We tested this assumption by studying the co-variation of archaeological and palaeoenvironmental records during the Holocene in eastern Fennoscandia. The reconstruction of population history is based on the summed probability distribution of archaeological radiocarbon dates, and environmental changes are tracked with locally available, high-resolution biological and physical proxies that are relevant in terms of hunter-gatherer food availability and population dynamics. The results show major population growth during the period of high summer temperature and high productivity of the terrestrial, lacustrine and marine ecosystems that occurred during 7500–5700 cal. yr BP. The growth was followed by an abrupt decline during 5500–4000 cal. yr BP correlating with the onset of late-Holocene cooling and a major forest ecosystem change brought about by the expansion of Norway spruce and the associated change from species-rich mixed forests to a conifer-dominated boreal ecosystem. Forest ecosystem changes likely enforced the negative effects of decreasing productivity on hunter-gatherer food availability. The link between population and environmental proxies breaks down along with the intensification of agriculture after 3500 cal. yr BP, which indicates that agriculture weakened the environmental forcing on long-term human population dynamics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Because archaeologists and anthropologists are increasingly recognizing the effects of human population size on cultural variability and change (e.g. Henrich, 2004; Kennet et al., 2009; Kline and Boyd, 2010; Powell et al., 2009; Shennan, 2000, 2001; Steele and Shennan, 2009), it has become important to study the causes of variation in population size itself. Life history theory predicts that resource availability would affect the severity of so called life-history trade-offs, such as the one between the maximum number of offspring that can be produced and the maximum number that can reach the stage of being successful parents themselves (Hill and Hurtado, 1996; Shennan, 2009). Increasing the amount of resources would decrease these severities and eventually lead to population expansion. For humans, this link between resource availability and reproductive success seems to hold at least in preindustrial settings (Hill and Hurtado, 1996; Pettay et al., 2007) and therefore the extrinsic factors, such as climate, that affect environmental productivity and the potential abundance of food resources are relevant when searching for causes of human population fluctuations. This is especially pertinent for hunter-gatherers, who depend on natural plant and animal resources for their survival.

The notion of a dependent relationship between environmental productivity and population size is supported by the ethnographic record of hunter-gatherers, which provides evidence for correlations between population size and general climatic parameters, such as temperature and precipitation (e.g. Binford, 2002; Birdsell, 1953). Diachronic evidence for climate–population dynamics is, however, more ambiguous. Several archaeological studies have argued for a rough correlation between climatic and demographic proxies (e.g. Fidel and Kuzmin, 2007; Gamble et al., 2005; Gil et al., 2005; Louderback et al., 2010; Moreno et al., 2009; Munoz et al., 2010; Riede, 2009a; Smith et al., 2008; Williams et al., 2010), but the observed relationships are not always unequivocal. Ambiguity may result from the use of global climatic measures that can mask significant geographical heterogeneity in the climate history. The selection of poorly representative archaeological or environmental and climatic proxy measures can lead to spurious correlations or prevent us from uncovering salient linkages between data. For example, marked regional variability can be observed in the mid-Holocene temperature patterns in Europe alone (Davis et al., 2003), thus invalidating the use of general temperature records provided, for example, by the Greenland ice core δ18O data as a temperature surrogate over larger areas. Drawing reliable conclusions about human–environment interaction thus requires both high-quality archaeological data and physical proximity of the archaeological and palaeoenvironmental records, i.e. that the palaeoenvironmental proxies really track the environmental variability relevant to the people who left behind the archaeological record (see also Caseldine and Turney, 2010).

Owing to the availability of various suitable sedimentary deposits and a long research history, the Fennoscandian area in northern Europe provides numerous high-resolution biological and physical proxy records of the long-term dynamics of terrestrial, lacustrine and marine environments (Seppä et al., 2010). Therefore, it is an excellent region for testing hypotheses concerning potential environmental impacts on past human populations and cultures. Here, we utilize this opportunity and study the relationship between long-term hunter-gatherer population dynamics and environmental factors using Holocene archaeological and palaeoecological data from Finland, where Tallavaara et al. (2010) recently studied prehistoric population history using temporal frequency distributions of archaeological radiocarbon dates as a proxy of past population levels (see also Oinonen et al., 2010). In their analysis of the Holocene trend, Tallavaara et al. (2010) noted a period of remarkable growth and decline of the hunter-gatherer population between c. 7000 and 4500 cal. yr BP, which they tentatively linked to environmental change.

In this work, we test this link with a more comprehensive palaeoclimatic and palaeoecological data set. Because our research area lies in the southern and middle boreal zones of northern Europe, where the net primary productivity (NPP) of ecosystems is strongly correlated with temperature (e.g. Zheng et al., 2004), we first create a very simple baseline model that indicates how the hunter-gatherer population density would have varied during the Holocene if the annual mean temperature (AMT) was the sole determinant of the human carrying capacity. This model is based on ethnographic and temperature data, and it is thus independent of archaeological records. The modelled population pattern is then compared with a radiocarbon date-based population proxy distribution to detect possible deviations between these two patterns. Finally, we compare population patterns with proxy distributions of other climatic and environmental factors to determine whether these can explain the observed deviations and shed further light on the factors controlling hunter-gatherer population dynamics. We explore, in particular, whether moisture conditions and the productivity of aquatic environments play a role as well. We also compare the population history with the records of Holocene forest ecosystem changes during which species-rich temperate mixed forests turned into conifer-dominated boreal forests because this may have had an effect on hunter-gatherer food resources and population size.

sec.title: Palaeoclimatic and palaeoecological data
sec.p: Our primary palaeoenvironmental data come from the sediments of six small lakes (Figure 1). The temperature reconstruction is based on the combination of four high-resolution pollen records from which the AMT values (°C) are quantitatively derived. The technique is based on using modern pollen–climate calibration sets to create mathematical transfer functions that can be applied to fossil pollen assemblages to obtain quantitative reconstructions of one or two key climate parameters that usually exert the strongest influence on modern and past vegetation patterns and gradients in the study area (see Heikkilä and Seppä, 2003; Ojala et al., 2008; Sarmaja-Korjonen and Seppä, 2007; Seppä et al., 2004, 2009a). For comparison, we also present a reconstruction of the temperature trend from Greenland that is based on δ18O data from the North GRIP ice-core (Vinther et al., 2009).

caption.p: Map of the research area. Shading indicates the spatial coverage of the radiocarbon date data set. Dots indicate the origins of palaeoclimatic and palaeoecological data: 1, Lake Kirkkolampi; 2, Lake Saarikko; 3, Lake Laihalampi; 4, Lake Nautajärvi; 5, Lake Arapisto; 6, Lake Kuivajärvi

sec.p: Hydroclimatic conditions in the research area are tracked with cellulose-inferred oxygen isotope values (δ18O) of the sediment that reflect the general water volume of Lake Saarikko in eastern Finland (Figure 1) (Heikkilä et al., 2010). The water volume, in turn, is controlled by the effective precipitation, i.e. the outcome of precipitation and evapotranspiration.

The changes in forest composition are inferred from the pollen percentage values of Norway spruce (Picea abies) and other key boreal and temperate thermophilous tree taxa (Corylus, Quercus, Tilia, Ulmus) in pollen records from Lake Kirkkolampi (Alenius and Laakso, 2006), Lake Laihalampi (Heikkilä and Seppä, 2003) and Lake Nautajärvi (Ojala and Alenius, 2005; Ojala et al., 2008). These three records were selected because they form an east-to-west transect across southern Finland. Previous investigations of the forest history in this region have shown that the most striking Holocene forest composition change occurred along this transect and that this partly climate-independent change is associated with the gradual invasion and expansion of Norway spruce (Seppä et al., 2009b).

In eastern Fennoscandia, lakes, rivers and the Baltic Sea have provided significant resources for humans throughout the Holocene. We use two records to track the productivity of freshwater environments. The first record measures the annual accumulation of organic matter in Lake Nautajärvi. This record reflects the autochthonous primary production of the lake (Ojala and Alenius, 2005), which in turn is linked to the length and temperature sum of the primary production season (Ojala et al., 2008). The other record measures the nitrogen content of the sediment of Lake Saarikko (Heikkilä et al., 2010).

In addition to temperature, the productivity of the Baltic Sea is further affected by the inflow of saline North Atlantic waters (e.g. Möllmann et al., 2000; Ojaveer et al., 1998; Sohlenius et al., 2001; Vuorinen et al., 1998; Westman and Sohlenius, 1999). During its Holocene history, the Baltic Sea has faced alternating fresh and brackish water stages. The latest brackish water stage, the Litorina Sea, began around 8500 cal. yr BP, when the Danish Straits opened and seawater entered the Baltic basin. The subsequent salinity variation has been controlled by meteorological conditions, freshwater input to the Baltic Sea and the change in the inlet cross-section area at the Danish Straits (Gustafsson and Westman, 2002), which is the most important non-climatic factor. The cross-section area was at its maximum between 6000 and 5000 cal. yr BP (Gustafsson and Westman, 2002).

Currently, we do not have a direct proxy record of the productivity of the Baltic Sea along the Finnish coast – a drawback which reflects the general scarcity of available palaeoproductivity or resource abundance records in the Baltic area, but also one that can be overcome in the future as new data are produced. However, because the productivity of the Baltic Sea is largely controlled by the temperature and inflow of saline water, we indicate the period of the highest salinity according to proxy data given in Gustafsson and Westman (2002). We assume that the likeliest productivity peak of the sea occurs when the highest temperatures and strongest marine influence coincide.

sec.title: Ethnographic data and the model
sec.p: The hunter-gatherer data base compiled by Binford (2001) offers information about the environment of ethnographically documented hunter-gatherers such as annual mean temperature, annual mean rainfall, primary productivity and primary biomass. The data base also includes estimates of population size and density (persons/100 km2). Ethnographic density estimates are prone to error because ethnographers usually work with limited information about the actual size of the population and its territory and often rely on second-hand historical accounts. Thus, it is not surprising that estimates of the same group vary between different ethnographers, which can be seen, for instance, in the slight differences between Binford’s data base and the smaller data base compiled by Kelly (1995). It appears that Binford (2001) has been more conservative than Kelly (1995) by choosing smaller estimates from the available values. The difference is, however, not systematic.

While it is useful to keep this issue in mind, we still assume that the reliability of the density estimates is sufficient for our purposes. We aim to understand how AMT affects the hunter-gatherer population density in the ethnographic sample and use this information together with reconstructed Holocene temperatures to project an expected past population pattern of our study area. This is done by first fitting a regression model (density = f (AMT)) to the ethnographic data and by then inputting Holocene temperatures to the model to achieve an expected temporal distribution of hunter-gatherer population densities. By comparing the modelled population pattern with the ‘actual’ proxy pattern, it is possible to determine if factors other than AMT and factors linearly related to it affected population variability.

In the modelling, we used a subset (N=198) of Binford’s data set that includes hunter-gatherer populations from the arctic to the temperate zone (−20°C < AMT < 15°C). The distribution of population density in this sample is highly skewed (Figure 2A), and the relationship between density and temperature is not linear (Figure 2B). Therefore, we used the glm-function in the R -statistical software (R Development Core Team, 2010) to fit a generalized linear model with a gamma error distribution and a log link function to these data. A non-linear relationship between AMT and population density means also that the expected population pattern created using the regression model will not be an exact replica of temperature variability because the population peaks and troughs will be more pronounced.

caption.p: (A) The distribution of population density in the ethnographic sample of hunter-gatherers (Binford, 2001). (B) The relationship between annual mean temperature and hunter-gatherer population density

sec.p: The results of the model fitting to the ethnographic dataset are presented in Table 1. The explanatory power of such a simple model is rather weak, but this is not a major concern in our case because we are not interested in predicting actual population densities. The important thing is that AMT has a statistically significant effect on the hunter-gatherer population density. This means that, by inputting reconstructed AMT values, Equation (1) can reasonably be used to determine how a hunter-gatherer population would have varied throughout the Holocene if AMT was the only influence on human carrying capacity.

sec.title: Archaeological data
sec.p: Use of the temporal frequency distribution of radiocarbon dates as a proxy for population size is based on the idea that the frequency of 14C dates reflects the strength of the archaeological signal, which should correlate with prehistoric population size (e.g. Gamble et al., 2005; Riede, 2008; Shennan and Edinborough, 2007; Surovell et al., 2009). We used 1404 archaeological 14C dates gathered from the southern and central parts of Finland (Figure 1) as a basis for the reconstruction of population history. These dates form a subset of a larger data set that was evaluated against possible research biases, sample material deterioration and own age effects by Oinonen et al. (2010). They show that the pattern of date distribution has remained the same throughout the history of radiocarbon dating in Finland and that only relatively small differences in date distributions exist between different date submitter classes. This suggests that research biases do not have a strong effect on the date distribution. Although some taphonomic biases related to the sample material are evident, they do not determine or overly skew the general distribution of dates. The correction procedure for systematic taphonomic bias (Surovell et al., 2009) does not change the pattern for the period in question (Oinonen et al., 2010). Finally, more geographically and temporally restricted archaeological proxies independent of our 14C data set show patterns similar to those of the radiocarbon data and further support its validity as an indicator of the strength of the archaeological signal and thus past population levels (Tallavaara et al., 2010).

In this article, we present the radiocarbon date data by plotting the summed probability distribution of dates using the OxCal program and Intcal09 calibrating curve (Bronk Ramsey, 2009; Reimer et al., 2009). Before summing individual probability distributions, it is necessary to reduce the effect of site phases with multiple dates because these can distort conclusions based on the distribution. We follow the procedure described in Tallavaara et al. (2010), where the dates are combined by calculating a weighted average for the dates from the same site falling in 200 14C-yr intervals. We use only these combined dates (N=869) in this article.

The data set covers a period from 10 000 cal. yr BP up to c. 700 cal. yr BP, but since we are interested in hunter-gatherer populations, we focus mainly on the period prior to the adoption of agriculture, although we will present and briefly discuss the entire time range. The spatio-temporal dynamics of the adoption of farming economies in Finland are rather complicated (e.g. Taavitsainen et al., 1998, 2007). The firmest pollen evidence for the earliest cultivation in the southern part of the research area dates nevertheless to c. 4000 cal. yr BP, whereas the first macrofossil evidence is c. 500 yr younger (Vuorela, 1998, 1999; Vuorela and Lempiäinen, 1988). There are also sporadic indications in the pollen record that may extend the beginning of small-scale cultivation to a considerably earlier date of c. 5000 cal. yr BP (Mökkönen, 2010). Therefore, we assume that the radiocarbon data exclusively represent hunter-gatherers until that period, and it is known that hunting, gathering and fishing remained an important and, in many areas, a sole mode of production even after that period.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Figure 3 shows the archaeological population proxy together with the reconstructed Holocene temperature values and the expected population pattern. The differences in the Holocene temperature trends of Greenland and Finland are apparent because the highest temperatures are reached c. 2000 yr later in the Finnish data. This results in poor correlation between ice core data and the modelled population pattern, and the correlation is even weaker with the archaeological population proxy. The latter indicates very low early-Holocene population levels, a rise that begins around 8000 cal. yr BP, a remarkable peak at c. 5600 cal. yr BP and a subsequent decline that turns to new growth at c. 3500 cal. yr BP along with the gradual adoption and intensification of agriculture.

caption.p: Comparison of the reconstructed Holocene temperatures, modelled population density (with LOWESS smoother of a span of 0.05) and archaeological population proxy. Modelled densities are derived from Equation (1) by inputting reconstructed Holocene AMT values in it. See Vinther et al. (2009) for the Greenland temperature reconstruction

sec.p: A comparison of the archaeological proxy record with the modelled population trend reveals similar outlines in both patterns until 3500 cal. yr BP after which the correlation between the model and proxy data breaks down completely. Both patterns show early- to mid-Holocene population growth that peaks at around 5600 cal. yr BP and then becomes negative. Despite the overall similarity, these patterns differ in the relative strength of the population peak, this being more pronounced in the proxy data than in the model. The difference suggests that the annual mean temperature does not solely explain variability in hunter-gatherer population size in our study area.

In Figure 4A population patterns are plotted along with proxies that reflect moisture conditions and aquatic productivity. The oxygen isotopic record reflects the summer lake-level status through the strong role of evaporative enrichment of δ18O during the summer (Heikkilä et al., 2010). This isotopic record is consistent with other lake-level investigations that have been carried out, particularly in Sweden (Almquist-Jacobson, 1995; Digerfeldt, 1972) and Finnish Lapland (Hyvärinen and Alhonen, 1994; Korhola et al., 2005). All of the records point to a fall of the water-table during the Holocene thermal maximum, at roughly 8000–4000 cal. yr BP, followed by a rising water-table during the last 4000 years in response to lower temperature and associated lower evapotranspiration or higher precipitation or both. The fact that the mid-Holocene was not just a warm, but also a relatively dry period, results in a negative correlation between population size and effective precipitation.

caption.p: (A) Population size and the indicators of hydroclimate and aquatic productivity with LOWESS smoother of a span of 0.05. Salinity variation of the Baltic Sea is indicated according min. and max. proxy values given in Gustafsson and Sohlenius (2002). (B) Population history and the forest ecosystem change. Average proportions of temperate tree taxa (Corylus, Quercus, Tilia, Ulmus) are shown together with three pollen records from different parts of Finland illustrating the gradual east–west expansion of Norway spruce (Picea abies)

sec.p: Among the indicators of aquatic NPP, the nitrogen levels of Lake Saarikko appear to have no real correlation with population size, whereas the organic varve thickness record of Lake Nautajärvi shows a distinct peak between 6000 and 5500 cal. yr BP and is therefore highly similar to the population proxy. As mentioned above, varve thickness reflects the strength and length of the primary production season and is related to summer temperatures. It is thus likely that it tracks, not only the strength of the aquatic NPP, but also general ecosystem productivity. However, this does not seem to be true for the last 2500 yr, since the increased varve thickness during this period does not solely reflect natural productivity, but may instead be partly due to human influences (Ojala et al., 2008).

The trends in population size and the Baltic Sea salinity appear to be very similar as well. Salinity reached its peak between 6000 and 5000 cal. yr BP mainly as a result of the stronger inflow of marine waters allowed by the increased cross-sectional area of the Danish Straits. Because this period of strong inflow coincides with the highest summer temperatures, it is likely that the period also represents the productivity peak of the Baltic Sea.

In addition to different productivity indicators, we explored a possible link between hunter-gatherer population size and major changes in the forest ecosystem. Palaeoecological research has shown that a major forest-composition change occurred during the Holocene in Fennoscandia as Norway spruce gradually invaded the region from the east. Norway spruce eventually became the dominant species by outgrowing and suppressing the temperate deciduous taxa, particularly lime, that formed the forests prior to the spruce expansion (Seppä et al., 2009b). Figure 4B shows changes in the proportions of temperate tree taxa and Norway spruce in the pollen record of southern Finland. This comparison suggests a striking correlation with the timing of the forest ecosystem change and the population size in Finland, with the peak population dating to 6000–5500 cal. yr BP just before the rise of Norway spruce, which corresponds with the population decline.

sec.title: Hunter-gatherers under environmental forcing
sec.p: The correlations between archaeological and several environmental proxies during the early and mid Holocene support the idea that changes in climate and environment have had a strong impact on long-term hunter-gatherer population dynamics in general and on the mid-Holocene population peak in particular. It seems clear that temperature was generally important because the outlines of archaeological proxy data neatly follow the model that assumes only the annual mean temperature as an explanatory factor. It is, however, the strength and length of the primary production season as measured by the organic varve thickness of Lake Nautajärvi that show the strongest link with the prehistoric hunter-gatherer population size. This is not surprising since, in terms of the availability of terrestrial and aquatic foods and consequently human carrying capacity, the duration and intensity of production are more direct indicators than the annual mean temperature. The strong correlation between hunter-gatherer population size and NPP further indicates that it is the summer temperature and its effect on food abundance rather than the winter temperature and its possible effects on death rate that exert a stronger influence on long-term hunter-gatherer population dynamics.

While the correlation between population size and temperature is evident and theoretically sound, the negative correlation between population size and effective precipitation is somewhat unexpected. Recent attempts to model the effects of climate change on the NPP of the boreal ecosystem have indicated that rising temperatures can cause a remarkable increase in production if they are accompanied by increased moisture, whereas only a minimal or negative increase in production may result if dryness should increase (Bergh et al., 2003; Briceño-Elizondo et al., 2006; Kang et al., 2006; Price et al., 1999). However, these predictions use the modern forest ecosystem as a starting point, and therefore, increasing dryness would have a negative effect on productivity mainly through moisture-demanding species such as spruce (Bradshaw et al., 2000; Briceño-Elizondo et al., 2006; Price et al., 1999), which did not dominate the forests of eastern Fennoscandia during the early and mid Holocene. Because the forest ecosystem changed during the Holocene, these models may not be valid in the mid-Holocene context. Rather, the results presented here suggest that the dryness was not sufficiently severe to counter the positive effects of temperature.

Although partly independent of climate, the forest ecosystem change roughly correlates with the climate change. Thus, it is difficult to determine whether it was the climate-controlled NPP as such or changes in the forest composition and structure that had a more profound effect on food abundance and consequently on hunter-gatherer population size. As Table 2 shows, there is nevertheless a difference in animal biomass between coniferous and mixed forests, and it is thus reasonable to assume that the change from mixed temperate forests to typical conifer-dominated boreal forests affected food availability. Because of the intense human impact on modern forest ecosystems, the figures in Table 2 are not direct analogues for actual prehistoric biomasses, but the relative differences are still clear: a higher animal biomass is seen in the temperate mixed forest than in the boreal forest. This is evident for the whole animal biomass as well as for single species such as moose.

caption.p: Differences in animal biomass between different forest types. Moose biomass is calculated using average weight of 300 kg and the mean of decadal population density data (1940–1995) given in table 6.11 of Baskin and Danell (2003)

sec.p: Although the modern biomass differences partly relate to climate, through differences in growing season length, it is still likely that the differences in forest structure and chemical characteristics of soils also exert a strong influence. Coniferous species, especially spruce, effectively shade out herbaceous, shrub and immature tree growth in the understory, thus reducing the abundance of important food sources, e.g. for ungulates (Mellars, 1975). The negative effect of shading on the undergrowth is further enforced by acidic litter, which decreases soil fertility (e.g. Koptsik et al., 2001; Levula et al., 2003; Wallrup et al., 2006). Thus, the ecosystem change from species-rich temperate mixed forests to typical boreal forests would have had a negative effect on hunter-gatherer food availability. In the absence of substantial mitigating technological changes (for which there is no archaeological evidence), such a reduction in the availability of food, i.e. a net reduction in carrying capacity, is expected to have contributed significantly to the simultaneous population decline.

Given the importance of fish and seals in the diet of hunter-gatherers under study here, the productivity of the Baltic Sea may have also played an important role in population dynamics. The cross-sectional area at the Danish Straits, which constrain the inflow of saline marine water into the Baltic basin, changed almost in concert with the climate, thus enforcing the climatic effect on the productivity of the Baltic Sea. The most conspicuous change in the archaeo-faunas in Finland and neighbouring areas is the rise of the proportion of aquatic species from c. 8000 cal. yr BP onwards, which is coincident with the beginning of the brackish water Litorina stage of the Baltic Sea (Enghoff et al., 2007; Kriiska, 2001; Núñez, 1990; Siiriäinen, 1982; Ukkonen, 1993). This rise is initially quite modest, but aquatic species such as seals start to dominate the faunal assemblages of coastal sites from c. 7200 cal. yr BP (Núñez, 1990; Siiriäinen, 1982; Ukkonen, 1993). The corresponding proportion of fish and water fowl rise slightly later between 5900 and 5500 cal. yr BP, after which the proportion of aquatic species starts to slowly decline (Mannermaa, 2008; Núñez, 1990; Siiriäinen, 1982). The increase in the use of aquatic resources coincides thus with the rising aquatic productivity, which suggests that aquatic productivity may have had a relatively important role in the rapid growth of hunter-gatherer populations during the mid Holocene.

Because of the complex and partly linear relations between the forcing variables considered here, we cannot, however, fully quantify the relative importance of the different environmental factors affecting past hunter-gatherer population dynamics in Fennoscandia. It is nevertheless clear that there were several interwoven factors forcing population size in the same direction. The link between population size and environment, especially NPP, appears to be so strong that there is no need to evoke cultural factors, such as migration or technological innovation, to explain the outlines of the observed pattern in the archaeological population proxy for the early to mid Holocene. Therefore, although we cannot rule out these factors, we attribute the main causality of long-term hunter-gatherer population fluctuations in the study area to changes in the carrying capacity, which has been controlled or strongly influenced by climate trends or indirectly climate-related environmental factors (see Figure 5).

caption.p: The model summing up relevant environmental factors and their hypothesised effects on hunter-gatherer population size during the Holocene in eastern Fennoscandia. The direction of correlation is indicated by +/− signs. We suggest that the food abundance is strongly influenced by the factors affecting ecosystem NPP as well as the changes in the forest structure and composition that had direct effect on animal biomass (Table 2)

sec.p: The proposition of a causal link between the environment and the hunter-gatherer population is not novel. However, the relative effects of different environmental factors vary between regions, depending on their importance for human health and fertility, either directly or via food abundance. For example, the effects of the Holocene thermal maximum in the Great Basin of the western USA were opposite to those of Fennoscandia. In this region, the availability of water is an important factor controlling the terrestrial NPP and the ecosystem carrying capacity, and the warm and dry conditions of the mid Holocene therefore caused a decline in the hunter-gatherer population (Louderback et al., 2010). Similarly, variations in population size in Australia have been linked to ENSO activity that affects precipitation in the area (Smith et al., 2008; Williams et al., 2010). However, the correlation between environment and population size in this region currently appears less well resolved because the archaeological record also shows strong signals during some of the drier periods.

A degree of ambiguity is also evident for the Late Pleistocene records of Siberia and central and western Europe, where temperature is usually regarded as the most important controlling environmental factor. In both areas, the hunter-gatherer population expanded during the cold Oldest Dryas period, c. 18 000–15 000 cal. yr BP, before the onset of the warm Bølling interstadial at 14 700 cal. yr BP (Fidel and Kuzmin, 2007; Gamble et al., 2005). This indicates that hunter-gatherer population growth was not bound too tightly to increasing temperatures. The subsequent population decline in Europe nevertheless correlates with the dramatic climate shift of the Younger Dryas (Gamble et al., 2005). Recently, Riede (2009a, b) and Riede et al. (2009) have also suggested that abrupt climatic cooling during the Younger Dryas and 8200 cal. yr BP event caused crashes of hunter-gatherer population and consequent cultural changes.

Currently, the majority of evidence appears thus to be more in favour of abrupt and negative rather than positive effects of climate on forager population density, which supports Gamble et al.’s assertion (2005) that the primary influence of climate is on population decline rather than growth. However, while the Fennoscandian case discussed here is not directly comparable with earlier ones because of the inclusion of non-climatic environmental factors, it provides rather unambiguous evidence for the correlation between ameliorating climate and increasing hunter-gatherer population size. Such a correlation is also visible in data from the northeastern USA (Munoz et al., 2010), where the situation appears to be highly similar to that of Fennoscandia. In both areas, the hunter-gatherer population size peaked during the warm and dry period (c. 5400–3000 cal. yr BP in the NE USA), which also saw the highest pollen percentages of temperate deciduous tree taxa at the cost of coniferous species.

Additionally, the results from Finland and the northeastern USA indicate that not only abrupt climate shifts but also more gradual changes, such as the rise and decline of the Holocene thermal maximum, have had an impact on the long-term population trend on a regional scale. In fact, there is evidence suggesting that hunter-gatherers are rather unaffected by short-term interannual or decadal environmental fluctuations. Using high-resolution demographic and palaeoclimatic data, Helle and Helama (2007) showed that the population dynamics of the historical Sámi hunter-gatherers in northern Finland were not under climatic forcing. The reason that the historical and archaeological demographic records of Fennoscandia show different responses to external forcing are most likely related to the different temporal scales of these records. The millennial timescale of our study captures remarkable changes in environmental carrying capacity as compared with the rather short study period (c. 100 yr) of Helle and Helama (2007), during which the long-term mean temperature remained approximately the same despite interannual fluctuations. Helle and Helama (2007) may be correct in suggesting that hunter-gatherers have been rather well buffered against interannual environmental variability because of their dietary breadth (see also Rankama, 1996). However, as our results suggest, more enduring changes in the mean food abundance, caused either by density-dependent or environmental factors, eventually lead to changes in population size.

sec.title: Differing dynamics of foragers and farmers
sec.p: As mentioned above, the correlation between population size and environmental factors ceases from about c. 3500 cal. yr BP onwards, most likely due to the intensification of a farming economy. This indicates that the magnitude of the long-term temperature decline of c. 2°C during the late Holocene was not enough to severely retard the growth of the agricultural population on this super-regional scale. Also other archaeological and palaeoecological evidence from Finland and neighbouring areas shows that agriculture seemingly thrived throughout the cooling late Holocene (e.g. Asplund, 2008; Sillasoo et al., 2009) as well as during some of the colder anomalies such as the ‘Little Ice Age’ of the sixteenth century (Lagerås, 2007). Similarly, Munoz et al. (2010) noted that the rise in the agricultural population in the northeastern USA during the late Woodland period appears to have no link to climate.

Because short-term climatic variability is nevertheless known to have affected crop yields and consequently the size of farming populations (e.g. Eckstein et al., 1985; Pitkänen, 1993), our results suggest that the short- and long-term population dynamics of foragers and farmers are quite different with regards to climatic forcing. Even if climate-induced crop failures and famines were recurrent among farmers, they probably caused only short-lived population declines superimposed on the long-term population growth. A reason for this could be the geographical restrictedness of most crop failures (Holopainen and Helama, 2009), which would have permitted population growth over a larger spatial scale despite frequent but spatially non-synchronous local declines.

However, this idea of agricultural resilience against climate change may not be generally valid. There is increasing archaeological and genetic evidence that the earliest farming populations in central Europe associated with the Linear Pottery Culture (LBK) collapsed along with their economic system after c. 7000 cal. yr BP (Haak et al., 2005; Larson et al., 2007; Shennan and Edinborough, 2007). As Shennan and Edinborough (2007) suggest, such a synchronic decline over large areas could be the result of climate change. If this is true, farming techniques, cultivars and domestic animals must have become more resilient to climatic fluctuations during the Neolithic to facilitate the success of post-LBK farming populations. Future research could focus on investigating long-term environmental forcings of such agricultural populations operating at the edge of their niche space.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: One of the critical issues in studies of human–environment interactions is how to track environmental changes that were relevant to the people in question. Because there is considerable geographic variation in climate patterns, global climate proxies may not provide the best option, despite their wide usage. In this study, we overcame the potentially confounding effect of unrelated archaeological and environmental records by comparing archaeological population proxies from Finland with local high-resolution palaeoenvironmental and palaeoclimatic proxies. We found convincing correlation between hunter-gatherer population size and most of the environmental and climatic proxies, which is in line with predictions derived from ethnographic sources and life-history theory that assumes individual reproductive success and thus population size to correlate with resource availability (e.g. Shennan, 2002, 2009). Our main findings can be summarised as follows:

list-item.p: The long-term trends of the hunter-gatherer population size in eastern Fennoscandia correlate with temperature and especially with the summer temperature trends that have a direct link to ecosystem productivity. Changes in effective precipitation, however, do not seem to have had a strong impact on population size.

The forest ecosystem change from mixed temperate forests to typical conifer-dominated boreal forests coincides with the population decline at 5500–4000 cal. yr BP. It is likely that this change caused a decrease in the mammal biomass and game resources of the hunter-gatherers and acted together with cooling temperatures to erode their food security.
The hunter-gatherer population peak at 6500–5500 cal. yr BP is concurrent with the peak of the lacustrine productivity and the salinity and productivity of the Baltic Sea.

The correlation between environmental factors and population size breaks down from c. 3500 cal. yr BP onwards. The most likely reason for this is the gradual intensification of agriculture, which indicates that the adoption of agriculture clearly weakened climatic forcing on the long-term population dynamics of humans and created the ‘adaptive lag’ so characteristic of human societies (Laland and Brown, 2006).

sec.p: These results lead us to argue that environmental factors, through their impact on food abundance, strongly influenced the archaeologically visible changes in hunter-gatherer population size in general and the mid-Holocene boom-and-bust cycle in particular. Although the proposed model of a population–environment relationship (Figure 5) may be specific to our study region, the effects of temperature, ecosystem productivity and forest composition changes should have general relevance in temperate and boreal zones, where their effects can be tested in further studies.
